questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a polypeptide hormone?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is an example of a polypeptide hormone.

Cortisol is a steroid hormone. Adrenaline and thyroxine are derivatives of the amino acid tyrosine.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones According to their Chemical Structure

Proteins and polypeptide hormones

  • Large proteins (> 50 amino acids)
    • Anterior pituitary hormones: FSH, LH, GH, Prolactin
    • Parathyroid hormone
    • Insulin
  • Small peptides (< 50 amino acids)
    • Posterior pituitary hormones: Oxytocin, ADH
    • ACTH
    • Glucagon

Steroid hormones

  • Cortisol and aldosterone
  • Estrogen and progesterone
  • Testosterone
  • DHEA

Derivatives of a specific amino acid

  • Tyrosine
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Catecholamines
  • Tryptophan
    • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • Melatonin
  • Arginine
    • Nitric oxide

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

Thyroid hormones enter the nucleus and bind to thyroid hormone receptors. The hormone-receptor complex in the nucleus binds to DNA via zinc fingers. This increases the expression of a variety of different genes that code for proteins regulating cell function.  Although thyroxine is an AA derivative, there are transporters to move it into the cell, hence they are intracellular receptors acting on the nucleus.

Epinephrine, glucagon, and insulin bind to cell surface receptors.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is not stored before release?
questions.solution:
Cortisol is not stored before release.

Usually, the polypeptide and protein hormones such as insulin, thyroxine or renin are stored in secretory vesicles before release. They are synthesized as much larger polypeptide chains (preprohormones) that are biologically inactive and then processed intracellularly by specific proteases to yield the final hormone molecule which is stored in the secretory vesicle until needed.

On the other hand, steroid hormones such as cortisol are synthesised as needed and are not stored. They are lipid soluble and easily diffuse across cell membrane to enter the interstitial fluid and then blood.

questions.text: Downregulation of receptors occurs due to all except_____
questions.solution:
Downregulation of receptors occurs due to internalisation, inactivation of receptors or desensitisation.

A decrease in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to an increase in the level of active receptors. This is called upregulation of receptors.

On the other hand, an increase in the level of stimulating hormones generally leads to a decrease in the level of active receptors. This is called downregulation of receptors.

Downregulation of receptors can occur by one of the following mechanisms:

  • Desensitisation - Receptors undergo chemical modifications that make them less responsive.
  • Internalisation - It is the temporary sequestration of the cell membrane receptors to the inside of the cell, away from the action of hormones. Following internalisation, the receptors are either destroyed or recycled.
  • Inactivation of receptors.
  • Decreased production of receptors.

questions.text: Receptors on cell membrane that activate ion channel after binding with agonists are_____
questions.solution:
Nicotinic cholinergic receptors activate an ion channel after binding with its agonist. These receptors are called ligand-gated channels or ionotropic receptors.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:

  • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
    • Important for fast synaptic transmission.
    • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
  • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
    • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3) and opioid receptors.

questions.text: Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine act through_____
questions.solution:
Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine act through a 7 pass receptor called G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR).

The catecholamines act through GPCRs which are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR)?

choices.text: G proteins bind to hormones on the surface of the nucleus.
All the three subunits α, β, and ɣ should bind to each other for G proteins to act.
G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in α subunit.
G protein is bound to GTP in resting state.

questions.solution:
G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in α subunit.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors.

G proteins have 3 subunits (α,β and ɣ). In its resting state, α subunit is bound to GDP.

Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates G protein within the cell. The α subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP or Ca2+.

Once the ligand is unbound, the intrinsic GTPase activity of the α subunit converts GTP to GDP. This leads to reassociation of α with the β-ɣ subunit and termination of effector activation.

questions.text: Action of α subunit of G protein is_____
questions.solution:
The action of α subunit of G protein is the breakdown of GTP to GDP as it has an intrinsic GTPase activity.

Guanine exchange factors (GEFs) convert GDP to GTP by nucleotide exchange.

G proteins can be either stimulatory (GS) or inhibitory (Gi) with respect to the production of the 2nd messenger cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. Stimulatory or inhibitory activity resides in the α subunit.

  • Cholera toxin acts on α subunit of GS
  • Pertussis toxin acts on α subunit of Gi

questions.text: PDGF acts through which of the following signaling pathways?
questions.solution:
PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) acts through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

All growth factors that foster the multiplication or development of various types of cells act through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

questions.text: Which hormone acts on JAK-STAT kinase receptor?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone acts on JAK-STAT receptors.

Janus tyrosine kinase receptors (JAK-STAT) serves as receptors for:

  • Growth hormone
  • Prolactin
  • Erythropoietin
  • Leptin

Thyroxine acts on nuclear receptors. TSH and FSH act on G protein-coupled receptors.

questions.text: All of the following act through cell surface receptors except____
questions.solution:
Cortisol is a steroid hormone and acts on intracellular (cytoplasmic) receptor.

questions.text: Steroid hormone receptors have an attachment site for all except_____
questions.solution:
Steroid hormone receptors have an attachment site for steroid hormone, hormone-responsive element, and transcription activators, but not transcription repressors.

Transcription repressors are proteins that bind to specific sites on DNA and prevent transcription of nearby genes.

questions.text: True statement about second messengers is _____

choices.text: Are substances that interact with first messengers outside cells.
Mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters
Are hormones secreted by cells in response to stimulation by another hormone
Are substances that bind to first messengers in the cell membrane.

questions.solution:
Second messengers mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters.

Cell surface receptors are substances that interact with the first messengers which are hormones and neurotransmitters.

The second messengers are the intracellular signalling molecules. They bring about many short-term changes in cell function by altering enzyme function, triggering exocytosis, and other physiological effects. They can also lead to the alteration of transcription of various genes (long term effect).

Examples of second messengers are cAMP, cGMP, Ca2+ and IP3-DAG (Inositol triphosphate and diacylglycerol).

questions.text: Which one of the following acts as a second messenger?
questions.solution:
Among the following calcium (Ca2+) acts as a second messenger. 

Increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ binds to and activates calcium-binding proteins (calmodulin, troponin) or activate protein kinases (or phospholipase C) to bring about physiological effects.

Cytoplasmic Ca2+ is increased by:

  • Direct entry of Ca2+ from the ECF through Ca2+ channels that could be ligand-gated, voltage-gated or stretch-activated (mechanically gated).
  • Mobilisation of Ca2+ that are stored in high concentrations in the endoplasmic reticulum by other second messengers such as IP3-DAG (Inositol triphosphate and diacylglycerol).

questions.text: A primigravida with 38 completed weeks of gestation has gone into labor. Oxytocin was started to augment labor. The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is _____
questions.solution:
The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is the phospholipase C system.

It activates the enzyme phospholipase C which breaks down some phospholipids in the cell membrane into IP3 (phosphoinositol triphosphate) and DAG (diacylglycerol). DAG then activates protein kinase C and IP3 mobilises Ca2+ from mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum to bring about smooth muscle contraction and other cellular responses.

questions.text: cAMP is the exclusive second messenger for all the following except _________
questions.solution:
Vasopressin does not use cAMP exclusively.

Vasopressin (ADH) acts on at least 3 kinds of receptors: V1A, V1B and V2

  • All the 3 are G-protein coupled receptors
  • V1A and V1B receptors (Gq)  act through IP3 as a second messenger, to increase the intracellular calcium concentration
  • V2 receptors (Gs) use cAMP as a second messenger

cAMP is the exclusive second messenger for dopamine, corticotropin and glucagon.

Dopamine has 5 receptors (D1, D2, D3, D4, D5)

  • all use cAMP as second messengers
  • D1, D5 act by increasing cAMP
  • D2, D3, D4 act by decreasing cAMP

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of
questions.solution:
Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by cGMP.   

NO is a hormone derived from the amino acid arginine. It activates guanylyl cyclases in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger). cGMP activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, which causes blood vessels to relax. 

cGMP is the second messenger for nitric oxide and atrial natriuretic factor.

cGMP is a valuable drug target for the treatment of various pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases. Sildenafil decreases the degradation of cGMP & Riociguat stimulates soluble guanylyl cyclase resulting in increased cGMP activity. Both drugs are used in pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a second messenger?
questions.solution:
Guanylyl cyclase is the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of cGMP. It is cGMP that acts as the second messenger.

cAMP, IP3 and DAG are all second messengers.

questions.text: Activation of protein kinase C causes_____
questions.solution:
Activation of protein kinase C causes phosphorylation of proteins

Cellular Phosphorylation is under the control of two groups of proteins:

  • Kinases
    • enzymes that catalyse the phosphorylation of tyrosine or serine residues in protein
    • Example- Protein Kinase A, Protein Kinase C, Ca2+/Calmodulin Kinase
  • Phosphatases
    • that catalyses the dephosphorylation of tyrosine or serine residues in the protein

Kinases play important roles in regulating cellular physiology, including cell growth and cell death. Philadelphia chromosome, t(9:22) or the bcr-abl fusion gene codes for an abnormal kinase that leads to chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). The drug imatinib was developed to block the tyrosine kinase activity of bcr-abl protein and is an effective treatment option for CML.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. The parents also complain of early breast development, growth acceleration, and vaginal bleeding. On genetic studies, it was found that there is a gain of function mutation of G Protein. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most probable diagnosis is McCune-Albright syndrome as it is the only gain-of-function mutation of G Protein.

G proteins or G protein-coupled receptor complexes can undergo a loss- or gain-of-function mutation. Some examples are given below:

Receptor Type of mutation Disease
Cone opsin Loss Colour blindness
Rhodopsin Loss Night blindness or retinitis pigmentosa
Endothelin receptor Loss Hirschsprung disease
TSH receptor Loss Familial hypothyroidism
TSH receptor Gain Familial hyperthyroidism
LH receptor Gain Familial male precocious puberty
Gs protein Gain Pituitary adenomas with acromegaly
Gs protein Gain (mosaic) McCune-Albright syndrome

In McCune-Albright syndrome, a gain-of-function mutation in Gsα is associated with the rough-bordered areas of skin pigmentation and hypercortisolism. This mutation occurs during fetal development, creating a mosaic of normal and abnormal cells.

questions.text: Nuclear signalling pathways are all except
questions.solution:
Rat proteins are not nuclear signalling pathways. Recombinant rat IFN- is a bioactive protein intended for use in cell culture applications.

Importin:

  • Transporting protein molecules into nucleus by binding to specific recognition sequences, called Nuclear Localization Sequences (NLS).
  • 2 subunits, importin α and importin β.

Caveolins:

  • Family of integral membrane proteins that are principal components of caveolae membranes
  • Involved in receptor-independent endocytosis.
  • Acts as scaffolding proteins within caveolar membranes by compartmentalizing and concentrating signaling molecules.

NF-kB

  • Part of a prototypical proinflammatory signaling pathway
  • based on the role of NF-κB in the expression of proinflammatory genes including cytokines, chemokines, and adhesion molecules
